case_name: State of Tamil Nadu v. M/s. Cement Allocation Coordinating Organization

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 2300 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2300 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated October 18, 1967 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 637 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 18, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition.No. 637 of 1967.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant are Bishan Narain and A. V. Rangam.

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Narain and A. V. Rangam, for the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent are T. Desai and B. P. Maheshwari.

anchor.surface_text: T. Desai and B. P. Maheshwari, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hegde, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J.

facts.text: Petitioner before High Court is Ms. Cement Allocation Coordinating Organization, a selling agent of Dalmia Cement Bharat Ltd., referred to as assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner before the High Court is M s. Cement Allocation Coordinating Organization, a selling Agent of Dalmia Cement  Bharat  Ltd. That Organization will be hereinafter referred to as the assessee.

facts.text: On February 28, 1967, Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Lalgudi wrote to assessee to show cause why turnover relating to price of packing materials used in packing cement sold should not be included in taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28, 1967 the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Lalgudi wrote to the assessee to show cause why its turnover relating to the price of the packing materials used in packing the Cement sold should number be included in its taxable turnover.

facts.text: Assessee moved High Court of Madras under Article 226 instead of showing cause, seeking direction to assessing authority not to include that turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee instead of showing cause against that proposal moved the High Court of Madras under Article 226 of the Constitution to direct the assessing authority number to include that turnover in its taxable turnover.

facts.text: High Court entertained the Writ Petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court entertained that Writ Petition.

facts.text: Assessee averred in Writ Petition that it was functioning as agent of Dalmia Cement Bharat Ltd. and its rights are same as principal.

anchor.surface_text: In its Writ Petition the assessee had definitely averred that it was functioning as the agent of Dalmia Cement  Bharat  Ltd. and its rights are the same as that of its principal.

facts.text: Assessee alleged in Writ Petition that when cement sold in packages, packing charges were separately shown in bills issued to buyers.

anchor.surface_text: It was further alleged in the Writ Petition that when cement was sold in packages, the packing charges were separately shown in the bill,,, issued to the buyers.

facts.text: Assessee claimed entitled to deduct packing charges from total turnover under rule 6(c) of Rules under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On these grounds the assessee claimed that it is entitled to deduct those charges from its total turnover in view of rule 6 c  of the Rules framed under the Madras, General Sales Tax Act, 1959.

facts.text: Plea that assessee was agent of Dalmia Cement Bharat Ltd. during relevant period was not denied in return filed by State of Tamil Nadu.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the assessee that it was the Agent of Dalmia Cement  Bharat  Ltd. during the relevant period was number denied in the return filed by the State of Tamil Nadu.

facts.text: Fact that assessee showed packing charges separately in bills to purchasers of cement was not denied.

anchor.surface_text: It was also number denied that the assessee had shown the packing charges separately in the bills issued by it to the Purchasers of cement.

facts.text: High Court concluded on admitted facts that assessee entitled to deduct packing charges turnover if principals entitled had they sold cement directly.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of those admitted facts the High Court came to the companyclusion that the assessee is entitled to deduct from its total turnover the turnover relating to the packing charges if its principals would have been entitled to deduct the same had they sold the cement in question directly.

facts.text: High Court allowed the petition without costs.

anchor.surface_text: The operative portion of the High Court reads thus The petition is allowed but with numbercosts.

facts.text: High Court order does not prevent assessing authority from examining after fresh notice whether principal disentitled to exclusion of packing materials value.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, add that the order We have made in this petition does number in any way prevent the assessing authority from examining the question, after giving a fresh numberice, whether the principal himself would be disentitled to exclusion of the value of the packing materials in determining the chargeable turnover.

facts.text: State of Madras appealed to Supreme Court against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the State of Madras has companye up in appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate arises from the decision of the High Court of Madras in Writ Petition No. 637 of 1967.

facts.text: Commission agent is considered a dealer under section 2(g)(iii) of Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Because of section 2 g  iii  a Commission agent is also companysidered as a dealer for the purpose of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959.

facts.text: In the case, there were no express contracts of sale of packing materials between assessee and customers.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, it is number disputed that there were numberexpress companytracts of sale of the packing materials between the assessee and its customers.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that assessee entitled to claim exemption if principal could claim it.

anchor.surface_text: On that question, we agree with the view taken by the High Court.
Article 226 of the Constitution to direct the assessing authority number to include that turnover in its taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: rule 6 of the Rules framed under the Act. That rule reads The tax or taxes under section 3, 4 or 5 shall be levied on the taxable turnover of the dealer. In determining the taxable turnover, the amounts specified in the following clauses shall, subject to the companyditions specified therein, be deducted from the total turnover of a dealer - c all amounts falling under the following two heads, when specified and charged for by the dealer separately, without including them in the price of the goods sold freight and charges for packing, that is to say, companyt of packing materials and companyt of labour and other such like services.

concepts.interpretation: Allows deduction of packing charges from total turnover if charged separately without inclusion in price of goods.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction for separately charged packing costs in taxable turnover computation.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that we have to companysider is whether an agent of a principal who is also a dealer under the Act is entitled to the same rights as his principal has under the Act. Under the general law the agent merely represents his principal, Therefore, while functioning within the scope of the agency he can exercise all the rights which his principal companyld have exercised. In fact, in the case of an ordinary agency, the agent merely acts for Ms principal. This provision must hold good even under the Madras General Sales Tax Act unless otherwise provided therein.

concepts.interpretation: Agent represents principal and steps into his shoes, entitled to same rights and exemptions under the Act unless provided otherwise.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: specified number and handed them over to a customer in a cheap card-board companytainer of insignificant value, lie intended to sell the cardboard co

concepts.unlisted_description: Agent exercises principal's rights; deemed dealer status does not alter representational role for exemptions.

holdings.text: An agent of a principal who is also a dealer under the Act is entitled to the same rights as his principal has under the Act, including exemptions

anchor.surface_text: The first question that we have to consider is whether an agent of a principal who is also a dealer under the Act is entitled to the same rights as his principal has under the Act. Under the general law the agent merely represents his principal, Therefore, while functioning within the scope of the agency he can exercise all the rights which his principal could have exercised. In fact, in the case of an ordinary agency, the agent merely acts for Ms principal. This provision must hold good even under the Madras General Sales Tax Act unless otherwise provided therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agent represents principal under general law and steps into principal's shoes; this applies to the Sales Tax Act unless expressly altered, as deeming agent a dealer does not change this for exemptions.

holdings.text: The assessee is entitled to claim exemption in respect of packing charges if his principal could have claimed it had it sold the cement itself
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with High Court view based on agency principles; entitlement follows from principal's position since agent exercises principal's rights.

holdings.text: It is for the department to establish that a particular turnover constitutes part of the taxable turnover, considering all facts and circumstances

anchor.surface_text: Therein this Court has ruled that it is for the department to establish that a particular turnover constitutes a part or whole of the taxable turnover. For establishing that fact the department may call upon the assessee to produce before it such material which the assessee has in his possession or under his control.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Supreme Court precedent from Hyderabad Deccan Cigarette Factory case; department bears burden after reviewing assessee's materials and facts.

holdings.text: The determining factor whether packing charges form part of taxable turnover is whether parties intended to separately sell and buy the packing materials
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guidance from precedent in Hyderabad Deccan Cigarette Factory; consider circumstances, value, express/implied agreement; not deciding facts here.

holdings.text: High Court should preferably direct assessee to pursue statutory remedies before entertaining writ, but may proceed to merits if already entertained

anchor.surface_text: It would have been proper if the High Court had directed the assessee to put forward its case before the authorities under the Madras General Sales Tax Act 1959. Now that the High Court had entertained the Writ Petition and gone into the merits of the case, it serves no useful purpose to refuse to go into the merits of case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of alternative remedy prefers exhaustion of statutory process, but no useful purpose in remanding since merits already examined.
